para.paratext: Parol evidence is admissible when a writing does not show its plain meaning on its face.[1] It has been used to show that certain land is within the description in a deed,[2] to identify persons,[3] and to show what “rights, members and appurtenances” include in a deed.[4] However, it may not be used to reform a deed where the parol evidence is insufficient to determine the property being conveyed.[5] The Georgia courts have held that there is a marked distinction between explaining an ambiguous description by parol evidence and admitting parol evidence to supply a description.[6]

Having a merger clause in the writing does not prevent the use of parol evidence to explain ambiguities.[7] As stated by the Georgia Court of Appeals: “As we have many times held, unless there is an ambiguity unresolved by normal rules of construction, the court has the duty of interpreting contractual language and, absent ambiguity, will not look beyond the clear and express terms of the agreement.”[8]

In Travelers Insurance Co. v. Blakey,[9] the court divided the process of contract construction into three steps: (1) the court will determine the meaning of the contract as written, (2) if an ambiguity remains, the court will apply rules of construction that are provided for the guidance of the court, and (3) then, the jury will resolve any remaining ambiguity under proper instruction.[10]

The Georgia Supreme Court held in John Deere Company v. Haralson[11] that evidence identifying defendant's signature on a guarantee did not violate the parol evidence rule because the identification did not change or add to any of the terms in the guarantee agreement. Moreover, the Supreme Court overruled prior law and admitted parol evidence in a guaranty case where the debtor listed in the guaranty was a d/b/a of the underlying company.[12] The Court reasoned that “allowing a party to avoid a guaranty obligation he knowingly undertook simply because another party used a trade name, despite the fact that all parties to the agreement knew to whom the trade name referred, would undercut the purpose of the Statute of Frauds.”[13] Likewise, parol evidence is permitted to explain the meaning of technical terms used in a written contract.[14]

The Court of Appeals reversed the granting of summary judgment to a defendant where a parol contract was reached by the parties as to the percentage of ownership each party would have in an investment company, and thereafter the defendant admitted in writing several times that the plaintiff would retain 47% of the company.[15]

The Court of Appeals reversed the trial court where the trial court allowed a defendant to testify that beneficiaries under a trust were all over the age at which said trust was scheduled to terminate. The court held that no ambiguity existed under the four corners of the writing, and therefore the trial court erred by allowing the parol evidence.[16]
McCormick on Evidence §§ 205 to 207 (6th ed.).

Unambiguous language in a contract capable of only one reasonable interpretation is afforded its literal meaning, and plain words are given their usual significance; but technical words, or words of art, or words used in a particular trade or business, will be construed, generally, to be used in reference to this peculiar meaning. 4 G Properties, LLC v. GALS Real Estate, Inc., 289 Ga. App. 315, 656 S.E.2d 922 (2008).

But see Durden v. Reynolds, 264 Ga. 34, 440 S.E.2d 170 (1994). If the description is too vague, in that property cannot be located or parol evidence would in any way change the description contained in the deed, parol evidence may not be used. In Durden, parol evidence could not be used, resulting in voiding the conveyance.
Kirkpatrick v. Brown, 59 Ga. 450, 1877 WL 3231 (1877).
Central Mortg. Co. v. Humphrey, 328 Ga. App. 474, 759 S.E.2d 896 (2014).
Singh v. Sterling United, Inc., 326 Ga. App. 504, 756 S.E.2d 728 (2014).

Wood v. Phoenix Ins. Co., 199 Ga. 461, 34 S.E.2d 688 (1945); Hanson v. Stern, 102 Ga. App. 341, 116 S.E.2d 237 (1960); Roca Properties, LLC v. Dance Hotlanta, Inc., 327 Ga. App. 700, 761 S.E.2d 105 (2014); Atlanta Development Authority v. Ansley Walk Condominium Association, Inc., 829 S.E.2d 858 (Ga. Ct. App. 2019).
Belvedere Builders, Inc. v. First American Title Ins. Co., 164 Ga. App. 535, 296 S.E.2d 245 (1982).
Travelers Ins. Co. v. Blakey, 255 Ga. 699, 342 S.E.2d 308 (1986).

Although the three steps were not specifically stated, the same approach was followed in Gans v. Georgia Federal Sav. & Loan Ass'n, 179 Ga. App. 660, 347 S.E.2d 615 (1986); Walton v. Datry, 185 Ga. App. 88, 363 S.E.2d 295 (1987); U.S. Fire Ins. Co. v. Cowley & Associates, 183 Ga. App. 478, 359 S.E.2d 160 (1987).

In construing contracts, trial court must first decide whether the contract language is ambiguous, and, if it is, trial court then applies the applicable statutory rules of contract construction. Quality Foods, Inc. v. Smithberg, 288 Ga. App. 47, 653 S.E.2d 486 (2007).

Trial courts must follow a three-step process for resolving issues of contract construction: court must first decide whether the contract language is ambiguous, and if it is ambiguous, court must then apply the applicable rules of construction; if after doing so the court determines that an ambiguity still remains, the jury must then resolve the ambiguity. Krogh v. Pargar, LLC, 277 Ga. App. 35, 625 S.E.2d 435 (2005).

If the court determines that an ambiguity exists with respect to the language of a restrictive covenant, a jury question does not automatically arise, but rather, the court must first attempt to resolve the ambiguity by applying the statutory rules of construction. Godley Park Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bowen, 286 Ga. App. 21, 649 S.E.2d 308 (2007); Holmes v. Clear Channel Outdoor, Inc., 284 Ga. App. 474, 644 S.E.2d 311 (2007); Covington Square Associates, LLC v. Ingles Markets, Inc., 283 Ga. App. 307, 641 S.E.2d 266 (2007); Lovell v. Thomas, 279 Ga. App. 696, 632 S.E.2d 456 (2006).
John Deere Co. v. Haralson, 278 Ga. 192, 599 S.E.2d 164, 166 (2004).
Colonial Oil Industries, Inc. v. Lynchar, Inc., 303 Ga. 839, 815 S.E.2d 917 (2018).
